questions.text: A previously healthy 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of irritability and poor feeding for 6 days. He has also not had a bowel movement in 9 days and has been crying less than usual. He is bottle-fed with formula and his mother has been weaning him with mashed bananas mixed with honey for the past 3 weeks. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears weak and lethargic. He is at the 50th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and delayed skin turgor. There is poor muscle tone and weak head control. Neurological examination shows ptosis of the right eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Human-derived botulism immune globulin against the botulinum toxin is the treatment of choice for infant botulism in children < 1 year of age because the risk of a hypersensitivity reaction is lower than with equine-derived antitoxins. In addition to antitoxin therapy, patients will also require extensive supportive care. The three most important supportive measures are 1. Placing the infant supine with the head tilted back at 30° to prevent aspiration of secretions; 2. Early prophylactic intubation to maintain a patent airway and facilitate mechanical ventilation in the event of respiratory muscle weakness; 3. Nasogastric or nasojejunal tube feeding.
Image Description:

This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

B) INCORRECT:

Penicillin is a beta-lactam antibiotic that is primarily used to treat infection with select gram-positive aerobes, including Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Actinomyces. S. pneumoniae may cause meningitis, which often manifests with poor feeding and irritability in infants, but poor muscle tone and constipation would be inconsistent with this diagnosis. The goal of treatment in this patient is to counteract the effect of botulinum toxins. Since antibiotics cannot counteract the effect of botulinum toxins, intravenous penicillin would not be an effective treatment for infant botulism.

C) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that is mainly used to treat infections caused by aerobic gram-negative rods and may be indicated in newborns for empiric therapy of bacterial meningitis. Although this patient presents with some signs of infant meningitis (e.g., irritability, poor feeding), poor muscle tone and constipation would not be consistent with this bacterial meningitis. This infant is also older than one month and thus no longer considered a newborn. Additionally, antibiotics, in general, cannot counter the effect of botulinum toxins, nor are aminoglycosides effective against anaerobes such as C. botulinum. In fact, aminoglycosides are contraindicated in botulism because they may exacerbate symptoms by causing neuromuscular blockade.

D) INCORRECT:

Equine-derived antitoxins are immunoglobulins that are derived from the blood of horses that have been immunized with a specific bacterial toxin/toxoid (e.g., botulinum toxin). Equine-derived antitoxins contain foreign proteins that can cause severe allergic reactions in infants and should therefore be avoided in infants with botulism < 1 year of age. The equine-derived heptavalent botulism antitoxin may, however, be used in adults and children > 1 year with wound botulism or food-borne botulism because the risk of hypersensitivity is lower in these patient groups. This type of antitoxin is also considerably cheaper than human-derived antitoxins.

E) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis refers to the separation of plasma from blood in extracorporeal circulation. The plasma is then either exchanged with normal plasma or filtered to remove pathological antibodies, immune complexes, and/or protein-bound toxins. Plasmapheresis is also a therapeutic option for immune-mediated neurological conditions such as Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). However, the diagnosis of GBS is unlikely in this infant because GBS typically manifests with ascending paralysis following certain gastrointestinal or respiratory tract infections.

F) INCORRECT:

Pyridostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that is used to treat myasthenia gravis. Infants with congenital myasthenic syndromes and juvenile myasthenia gravis can also present with feeding difficulty, poor head control, and ptosis. Here, however, the history of weaning with honey and the absence of a family history of myasthenia gravis suggest infant botulism as the more likely diagnosis. Pyridostigmine has been used in case reports as an experimental treatment for infant botulism in infants who did not respond to appropriate first-line treatment, but it is not routinely used for this condition.
questions.hint: Considering the boy's poor feeding, lack of bowel movements, weak head control, and exposure to honey, he most likely has botulism. Infant botulism is caused by Clostridium botulinum, spores of which may be present in honey. C. botulinum produces a toxin that is absorbed from the gut into the systemic circulation. This toxin blocks the release of acetylcholine from the motor endplate, which causes neuromuscular blockade, resulting in the symptoms seen here.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friends because of blurred vision and slurred speech for the past 6 hours. He had some difficulty swallowing his food during lunch and has weakness in both arms. Two weeks ago, he had an upper respiratory infection that resolved spontaneously. He lives independently and returned from his grandparents' farm 2 days ago. He commonly consumes home-canned vegetables and fruits. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 10/min and labored, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral nystagmus and ptosis. The pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. Muscle strength of the facial muscles and bilateral upper extremities is decreased. Upper extremity deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Toxin that inhibits GABA and glycine release

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Organophosphates are chemicals that work by irreversibly inhibiting the acetylcholinesterase enzyme, causing life-threatening activation of the parasympathetic nervous system. Although organophosphate poisoning commonly occurs on farms and causes weakness and paralysis, it is typically associated with increased salivation, diarrhea, uncontrolled urination, bronchospasm, and tremor. Additionally, increased acetylcholine activity would result in miosis rather than mydriasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is caused by the activation of autoreactive T-lymphocytes, which leads to focal demyelination and nerve destruction. Initial manifestations include internuclear ophthalmoplegia and retrobulbar neuritis, followed by loss of vibration and touch, upper motor neuron weakness, Charcot neurological triad, cranial nerve palsies, and autonomic dysfunction. Although this patient also has muscle weakness, hyporeflexia is not a typical finding of MS and instead suggests a problem originating from the lower motor neuron and/or the neuromuscular junction.

C) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is caused by autoantibodies against the acetylcholine (ACh) receptors that compete with ACh, causing generalized muscle weakness. Although MG manifests with weakness of the eye muscles, bulbar muscles, and proximal limbs, it most often occurs in young women and tends to worsen with increased activity. MG muscle weakness is generalized and more prominent in the proximal limbs, whereas this patient presents with weakness predominantly in the upper extremities. Also, MG usually follows a more gradual course with progression of symptoms over months to years. While this patient presents with hyporeflexia, deep tendon reflexes are typically normal in patients with MG.

D) INCORRECT:

Tetanus occurs when Clostridium tetani spores contaminate a wound (e.g., through dirt or saliva) and produces neurotoxins such as tetanospasmin. Tetanospasmin is transported to the CNS via retrograde axonal transport and prevents the release of GABA and glycine inhibitory neurotransmitters from interneurons, causing uncontrollable muscle contractions. Because this patient does not report any trauma, tetanus is unlikely. In addition, tetanus is characterized by the typical triad of trismus, risus sardonicus, and opisthotonus, rather than paralysis.

E) CORRECT:

Botulism is caused by botulinum toxin, which irreversibly inhibits acetylcholine release from motor endplates in the neuromuscular junction. Symptoms of botulism include cranial nerve abnormalities such as accommodation paralysis and mydriasis, which eventually result in peripheral flaccid paralysis that progresses caudally, causing difficulty swallowing, breathing, and weakness of the arms and legs. Foodborne botulism occurs when preformed toxins in foods contaminated with Clostridium botulinum are ingested. Botulinum toxins are most often found in home-canned foods and packed meats.
Image Description:

Left image: physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end plate
– Action potential reaches the motor end plate → SNARE protein complex facilitates the fusion of vesicles containing acetylcholine (ACh) with the prejunctional membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh with ACh receptors on the postjunctional membrane → opening of the ion channels of ACh receptors → depolarization of the muscle
– Acetylcholinesterase present on the postjunctional membrane breaks down ACh and releases it into the neuromuscular junction cleft → choline is taken up by the choline transporter on the prejunctional membrane and recycled in ACh synthesis

Right image: cleavage of SNARE proteins by botulinum toxin
– Botulinum toxin is endocytosed by cholinergic axon terminals (depicted in the left image)
– The light chain of botulinum toxin released into the prejunctional neuron cleaves the SNARE protein complex → failure of fusion of vesicles containing ACh with the presynaptic membrane → ACh is not released into the neuromuscular junction → neural impulse is not transmitted to the muscle → flaccid paralysis of the muscle

F) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is caused by autoantibodies against myelin. The condition usually occurs 1–4 weeks after an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infection and is characterized by flaccid paralysis. Although this patient has motor paralysis and had an upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago, paralysis in GBS is typically ascending and respiratory motor function is usually one of the latest clinical manifestations.
questions.hint: This patient's dilated pupils, labored breathing, speech and swallowing difficulties, and flaccidity, in combination with a history of home-canned foods consumption suggest foodborne botulism.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Six months ago, she was diagnosed with overactive bladder syndrome and began treatment with oxybutynin. She continues to have involuntary loss of urine with sudden episodes of significant bladder discomfort that is only relieved by voiding. A substance is injected into the detrusor muscle to treat her symptoms. The physician informs the patient that she will have transitory relief for several months before symptoms return and will require repeated treatment. The injected substance is most likely produced by an organism with which of the following microbiological properties?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis is a gram-negative, encapsulated diplococcus. Although N. meningitidis does not secrete exotoxins, the lipooligosaccharides on its outer membrane act as endotoxins. However, endotoxins have no role in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis is a gram-negative, aerobic coccobacillus. B. pertussis produces pertussis toxin, which plays a central role in the pathogenesis of whooping cough. However, it has no role in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a gram-positive, club-shaped rod. C. diphtheriae produces diphtheria toxin, which can cause pharyngitis with pseudomembranes and severe lymphadenopathy. However, diphtheria toxin has no role in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Vibrio cholerae is a gram-negative, comma-shaped rod that produces cholera toxin. This toxin causes voluminous “rice-water” diarrhea by permanently activating Gs alpha subunit, thus overactivating adenylate cyclase and increasing the level of cAMP, which subsequently increases Cl− secretion and H2O efflux in the gastrointestinal lumen. Cholera toxin is not used in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Botulinum toxin is produced by Clostridium botulinum, which is a gram-positive, spore-forming rod. Botulinum toxin is a protease that cleaves SNARE, thereby impairing the fusion of acetylcholine-containing vesicles with the presynaptic membrane of the motor end plates. This irreversibly inhibits acetylcholine release, resulting in muscle paralysis. Endoscopic injection of botulinum toxin at different points in the bladder wall suppresses involuntary bladder contractions and thus improves the symptoms of overactive bladder syndrome.
Image Description:

Left image: physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end plate
– Action potential reaches the motor end plate → SNARE protein complex facilitates the fusion of vesicles containing acetylcholine (ACh) with the prejunctional membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh with ACh receptors on the postjunctional membrane → opening of the ion channels of ACh receptors → depolarization of the muscle
– Acetylcholinesterase present on the postjunctional membrane breaks down ACh and releases it into the neuromuscular junction cleft → choline is taken up by the choline transporter on the prejunctional membrane and recycled in ACh synthesis

Right image: cleavage of SNARE proteins by botulinum toxin
– Botulinum toxin is endocytosed by cholinergic axon terminals (depicted in the left image)
– The light chain of botulinum toxin released into the prejunctional neuron cleaves the SNARE protein complex → failure of fusion of vesicles containing ACh with the presynaptic membrane → ACh is not released into the neuromuscular junction → neural impulse is not transmitted to the muscle → flaccid paralysis of the muscle

F) INCORRECT:

Both Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes are gram-positive, β-hemolytic cocci. S. aureus produces several toxins, such as toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 and exfoliative toxin A. S. pyogenes produces streptolysin O and erythrogenic exotoxin A. However, none of these toxins are used in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome.
questions.hint: The physician most likely injected botulinum toxin into this patient's detrusor muscle to provide relief for her refractory overactive bladder syndrome.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of diplopia, slurred speech, progressive upper extremity weakness, and difficulty swallowing for the past several hours. She had mild abdominal pain that resolved spontaneously after returning from her father's farm yesterday. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respirations are 11/min and labored, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral nystagmus and ptosis. The pupils are dilated and not reactive to light or accommodation. Muscle strength of the facial muscles and bilateral upper extremities is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Lack of immunization with polysaccharide fragments

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Oral ingestion of a preformed toxin of Clostridium botulinum (botulinum toxin), most commonly found in canned food (e.g., home-canned vegetables), can cause foodborne botulism. The incubation period usually ranges from 12 to 36 hours and, as in this patient, gastrointestinal complaints such as abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting may precede neurological symptoms. Life-threatening respiratory complications can occur if the phrenic nerve is affected and patients may require mechanical ventilation. Treatment consists of close monitoring, promoting bowel emptying, and administration of botulism antitoxin.
Image Description:

Left image: physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end plate
– Action potential reaches the motor end plate → SNARE protein complex facilitates the fusion of vesicles containing acetylcholine (ACh) with the prejunctional membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh with ACh receptors on the postjunctional membrane → opening of the ion channels of ACh receptors → depolarization of the muscle
– Acetylcholinesterase present on the postjunctional membrane breaks down ACh and releases it into the neuromuscular junction cleft → choline is taken up by the choline transporter on the prejunctional membrane and recycled in ACh synthesis

Right image: cleavage of SNARE proteins by botulinum toxin
– Botulinum toxin is endocytosed by cholinergic axon terminals (depicted in the left image)
– The light chain of botulinum toxin released into the prejunctional neuron cleaves the SNARE protein complex → failure of fusion of vesicles containing ACh with the presynaptic membrane → ACh is not released into the neuromuscular junction → neural impulse is not transmitted to the muscle → flaccid paralysis of the muscle

B) INCORRECT:

A skin bite by Ixodes tick is the cause of Lyme disease. Early neurological symptoms such as cranial nerve palsies (most commonly peripheral facial nerve palsy) may be the first disease manifestation. However, Lyme disease is not associated with acute descending flaccid paralysis. Even though this patient might have been infected at her father's farm, symptoms of disseminated Lyme disease would not be expected at this stage of disease. Moreover, other characteristic features of Lyme disease, such as fever, rash, and joint pain, are not present.

C) INCORRECT:

Exposure of wounds to Clostridium botulinum spores can cause wound botulism due to in-vivo production of botulinum toxin. Wound botulism presents with cranial neuropathies and descending paralysis as seen in this patient. However, it is not associated with GI symptoms but commonly involves fever and leukocytosis. Although this patient might have been exposed to C. botulinum spores at her father's farm, an infected wound would be expected to be seen. Moreover, wound botulism manifests after a longer incubation period (∼10 days).

D) INCORRECT:

Lack of immunization with polysaccharide fragments would not increase the risk of botulism, as there is no effective vaccine against Clostridium botulinum. Polysaccharide conjugate vaccines are helpful for prevention of infection with bacteria such as Haemophilus influenzae B and Streptococcus pneumoniae.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastroenteritis caused by Campylobacter jejuni, a comma-shaped rod, is the most common disease associated with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). GBS presents with bilateral cranial neuropathies and flaccid paralysis that may involve the respiratory muscles, as seen in this patient. However, paralysis usually spreads from the lower to the upper limbs in a “stocking‑glove” distribution, unlike this patient's descending paralysis. Moreover, initial symptoms of GBS typically include peripheral paresthesias, whereas this patient has no sensory deficits.
questions.hint: This patient presents with sudden onset of bilateral cranial neuropathies (dilated pupils, ptosis, facial weakness, speech and swallowing difficulties) and descending flaccid paralysis with possible involvement of the diaphragm (labored breathing). Her normal level of consciousness and lack of fever or sensory deficits make botulism the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of poor feeding, especially when trying to breastfeed. The mother also reports that the boy's grip is weak and that he is constipated. He has met all developmental milestones and his immunizations are up-to-date. His diet consists primarily of breast milk, applesauce, and oatmeal sweetened with honey. Physical examination shows diffuse weakness and decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are decreased throughout. Which of the following labeled processes in the cholinergic synapse is most likely directly affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A shows choline being transported into the presynaptic neuron, which is the rate-limiting step in the synthesis of acetylcholine. This process is inhibited e.g., by hemicholinium. Botulinum toxin, however, does not affect the uptake of choline.

B) INCORRECT:

B shows the synthesis of acetylcholine from choline and acetyl-CoA by the enzyme choline acetyltransferase. This enzyme is inhibited e.g., by bromoacetylcholine. Botulinum toxin, however, does not affect choline acetyltransferase.

C) INCORRECT:

C shows the uptake of acetylcholine into synaptic vesicles via the vesicular acetylcholine transporter. This process is inhibited e.g., by vesamicol. Botulinum toxin, however, does not affect the vesicular acetylcholine transporter.

D) CORRECT:

D shows exocytosis of acetylcholine-filled vesicles into the synaptic cleft. Botulinum toxin inhibits this process by cleaving the SNAP-25 SNARE protein that mediates the fusion of vesicles with the presynaptic membrane in response to a rise in intracellular Ca2+ concentration, which is caused by neuron depolarization. Without acetylcholine release into the synaptic cleft, muscle cells will not contract, leading to flaccid paralysis. Because botulinum toxin can inhibit cholinergic innervation of both nicotinic and muscarinic neurons, autonomic innervation of tear, sweat, and salivary glands can also be affected.
Image Description:

Muscarinic antagonists (e.g., atropine) competitively inhibit muscarinic Ach receptors.

Direct parasympathomimetics (e.g., pilocarpine) activate muscarinic Ach receptors.

Indirect parasympathomimetics (e.g., neostigmine) block the activity of acetylcholinesterase, increasing the amount of available acetylcholine. Thus, they indirectly activate muscarinic Ach receptors.

E) INCORRECT:

E shows the binding of acetylcholine to acetylcholine receptors on the postsynaptic neuron. At the neuromuscular junction, this process is inhibited by neuromuscular-blocking drugs (e.g., suxamethonium, rocuronium, or cisatracurium), which are used during anesthesia to cause paralysis. Muscarinic acetylcholine receptors can be blocked by atropine. Botulinum toxin, however, does not affect acetylcholine binding to the acetylcholine receptor.

F) INCORRECT:

F shows the action of acetylcholinesterase; this enzyme breaks down acetylcholine into choline and acetate for recycling by the presynaptic neuron, terminating stimulation of the postsynaptic neuron. At peripheral cholinergic neurons, acetylcholinesterase is inhibited reversibly by the drugs physostigmine, neostigmine and pyridostigmine, and irreversibly by organophosphates. Botulinum toxin, however, does not affect acetylcholinesterase.
questions.hint: This patient's diffuse weakness and constipation are most likely caused by the ingestion of C. botulinum spores that produce a potent neurotoxin. These spores are frequently found in honey.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old girl who is being breastfed is brought in for evaluation of constipation. Her parents report that for the past week, she has been stooling every other day instead of after each feed as she used to. She started eating poorly yesterday and is not her usual active self. She has had no fevers or signs of infection. Pregnancy and birth histories are unremarkable, and she is developing normally. There have been no changes in her living environment, except for the recent start of construction on a new apartment building next door.
Her vital signs are normal. She is resting comfortably and is easily rousable, but her eyes do not open fully, and pupillary constriction is sluggish. She has a weak cry, a poor suck, and poor head control. Her legs are in frog-legged position, and her arm can be pulled across her neck so that her elbow passes the midline of her chest. Her reflexes are substantially depressed in the arms but only slightly so in the ankles.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: MRI of the brain and spine
Genetic testing for mutations in the SMN1 gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetylcholine receptor antibodies are present in older patients with myasthenia gravis, a condition that can manifest with bulbar signs and ptosis but spares the pupils. Infants rarely present with autoantibodies, as infant myasthenic syndromes are typically antibody-negative. Infants with congenital myasthenia syndromes experience symptoms from the time of birth. Previous diagnostic procedures for myasthenia gravis included edrophonium (Tensilon) testing; however, given the drug’s potentially hazardous effects, the ice-pack test, antibody testing, or genetic testing may be performed.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is significant for hypotonia, and the most likely cause, given the history and other signs and symptoms, is infant botulism.

Classic signs of hypotonia include slip-through (the sensation that a child will slip through your grasp when lifting him or her under the arms), the scarf sign (the ability to extend an infant’s arm across the neck so that the elbow passes the midline chest), and frog-legged positioning (in which the patient has their hips abducted and extended to the sides, with their knees flexed). This patient is exhibiting signs of peripheral hypotonia, including depressed reflexes, substantial involvement of the peripheral muscle groups, and normal mental status. Central hypotonia is typically characterized by brisk reflexes, more prominent axial muscle involvement, and changes in cognition.

Infant botulism typically affects healthy children between the ages of 6 weeks and 6 months. Classic signs include lethargy, weak cry, poor feeding, and generalized hypotonia. Constipation may occur up to one week before the onset of other symptoms. Infant botulism results from ingestion of Clostridium botulinum spores in food or inhalation of aerosolized particles from soils, such as near construction sites. C. botulinum spores can colonize an infant’s gastrointestinal tract, producing botulinum toxin, which then binds the presynaptic motor neuron and prevents the release of acetylcholine and inhibits motor contraction. Treatment with botulinum immune globulin is likely to reduce the patient’s risk of requiring intubation, nasogastric tube feeding, and an extended hospital stay.

Key learning point: Constipation followed by lethargy, hypotonia, and descending paralysis in an infant should raise suspicion for botulism.

C) INCORRECT:

A lesion of the central nervous system (brain or spinal cord) typically manifests with increased reflexes; this patient has depressed reflexes, suggesting a peripheral process. Therefore, MRI imaging of the brain or spinal cord would not be helpful.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin is administered for Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). The descending paralysis in this patient is less consistent with GBS, which typically manifests with an ascending paralysis. The Miller Fisher variant of GBS can affect the cranial nerves and may manifest with a descending pattern of weakness, but it spares the pupils, making the diagnosis less likely in this infant.

E) INCORRECT:

Results of genetic testing of the SMN1 gene are abnormal in patients with spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), a genetic disorder causing anterior horn-cell death. SMA typically results in slowly progressive proximal, before distal, muscle weakness. This child’s tone and strength were normal until recently, making SMA less likely. Also, SMA spares the pupils, and this infant’s pupillary constriction is sluggish.

Botulism is caused by botulinum toxin, which irreversibly inhibits acetylcholine release from motor endplates in the neuromuscular junction. Symptoms of botulism include cranial nerve abnormalities such as accommodation paralysis and mydriasis, which eventually result in peripheral flaccid paralysis that progresses caudally, causing difficulty swallowing, breathing, and weakness of the arms and legs. Foodborne botulism occurs when preformed toxins in foods contaminated with Clostridium botulinum are ingested. Botulinum toxins are most often found in home-canned foods and packed meats.

Key learning point: Foodborne botulism is caused by ingestion of preformed botulinum toxin, which blocks acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions, leading to descending flaccid paralysis and cranial nerve dysfunction.
Image Description:

Left image: physiological neuromuscular transmission at the motor end plate
– Action potential reaches the motor end plate → SNARE protein complex facilitates the fusion of vesicles containing acetylcholine (ACh) with the prejunctional membrane → release of ACh into the synaptic cleft → reversible binding of ACh with ACh receptors on the postjunctional membrane → opening of the ion channels of ACh receptors → depolarization of the muscle
– Acetylcholinesterase present on the postjunctional membrane breaks down ACh and releases it into the neuromuscular junction cleft → choline is taken up by the choline transporter on the prejunctional membrane and recycled in ACh synthesis

Right image: cleavage of SNARE proteins by botulinum toxin
– Botulinum toxin is endocytosed by cholinergic axon terminals (depicted in the left image)
– The light chain of botulinum toxin released into the prejunctional neuron cleaves the SNARE protein complex → failure of fusion of vesicles containing ACh with the presynaptic membrane → ACh is not released into the neuromuscular junction → neural impulse is not transmitted to the muscle → flaccid paralysis of the muscle

E) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is caused by autoantibodies against myelin. The condition usually occurs 1–4 weeks after an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infection and is characterized by flaccid paralysis. Although this patient has motor paralysis and had an upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago, paralysis in GBS is typically ascending and respiratory motor function is usually one of the latest clinical manifestations.
questions.hint: This patient's dilated pupils, labored breathing, speech and swallowing difficulties, and flaccidity, in combination with a history of home-canned foods consumption suggest foodborne botulism.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old infant is brought to the Pediatrician with two days of constipation, poor feeding, and lethargy. The mother reports the baby is less active and has a weak cry. The mother denies any recent infections or fever. The infant is alert but shows generalized hypotonia with diminished deep tendon reflexes. Pupillary reactions are normal, and vital signs are stable.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital myasthenic syndrome typically presents with fatigable weakness and ocular involvement, such as ptosis, while maintaining deep tendon reflexes. It is a chronic condition, not characterized by acute onset or constipation. The diminished reflexes and short symptom duration in this infant are inconsistent with this syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Infantile botulism occurs when Clostridium botulinum spores germinate in an infant's immature gastrointestinal tract, producing botulinum toxin. This toxin blocks acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction, leading to descending flaccid paralysis. Clinical manifestations include generalized hypotonia, diminished deep tendon reflexes, poor feeding, and a weak cry. Constipation often precedes these symptoms, indicating early toxin effects. Normal pupillary reactions occur because the toxin selectively affects neuromuscular function, sparing certain autonomic pathways.

Key learning point: Infantile botulism presents with constipation, lethargy, poor feeding, and hypotonia due to neurotoxin effects, and should be considered in infants with acute neurological symptoms.
Image Description:

This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

C) INCORRECT:

Neonatal sepsis often presents with fever, hypothermia, and systemic signs, typically in infants under one month. This infant, at 3 months, has stable vital signs and normal pupillary reactions, which do not align with sepsis. The absence of maternal infection history further reduces the likelihood of sepsis.

D) INCORRECT:

Spinal muscular atrophy involves anterior horn cell degeneration, causing progressive muscle weakness and hypotonia. While hypotonia and a weak cry may suggest this disorder, constipation and poor feeding are not typical. Additionally, tongue fasciculations and respiratory decline, common in this condition, are absent here.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 6-month-old boy in the emergency department. He has a 6-day history of irritability and poor feeding. He has not had a bowel movement in 9 days and has been crying less than usual. He is bottle-fed with formula, and for the past 3 weeks, his mother has been weaning him with mashed bananas mixed with honey. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears weak and lethargic. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he has dry mucous membranes, delayed skin turgor, poor muscle tone, and weak head control. Neurological examination reveals right-sided ptosis. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis refers to the separation of plasma from blood in extracorporeal circulation. The plasma is then either exchanged with normal plasma or filtered to remove pathological antibodies, immune complexes, and/or protein-bound toxins. Plasmapheresis is also a therapeutic option for immune-mediated neurological conditions such as Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). However, the diagnosis of GBS is unlikely in this infant because GBS typically manifests with ascending paralysis following certain gastrointestinal or respiratory tract infections.

B) CORRECT:

Human-derived botulism immune globulin against the botulinum toxin is the treatment of choice for infant botulism in children < 1 year of age because the risk of a hypersensitivity reaction is lower than with equine-derived antitoxins. In addition to antitoxin therapy, patients will also require extensive supportive care. The three most important supportive measures are 1. Placing the infant supine with the head tilted back at 30° to prevent aspiration of secretions; 2. Early prophylactic intubation to maintain a patent airway and facilitate mechanical ventilation in the event of respiratory muscle weakness; 3. Nasogastric or nasojejunal tube feeding.

Key learning point: Human-derived botulism immune globulin is the preferred initial treatment for infant botulism in children under 1 year due to lower risk of hypersensitivity reactions compared to equine-derived antitoxin.
Image Description:

This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

C) INCORRECT:

Penicillin is a beta-lactam antibiotic that is primarily used to treat infection with select gram-positive aerobes, including Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Actinomyces. S. pneumoniae may cause meningitis, which often manifests with poor feeding and irritability in infants, but poor muscle tone and constipation would be inconsistent with this diagnosis. The goal of treatment in this patient is to counteract the effect of botulinum toxins. Since antibiotics cannot counteract the effect of botulinum toxins, intravenous penicillin would not be an effective treatment for infant botulism.

D) INCORRECT:

Pyridostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that is used to treat myasthenia gravis. Infants with congenital myasthenic syndromes and juvenile myasthenia gravis can also present with feeding difficulty, poor head control, and ptosis. Here, however, the history of weaning with honey and the absence of a family history of myasthenia gravis suggest infant botulism as the more likely diagnosis. Pyridostigmine has been used in case reports as an experimental treatment for infant botulism in infants who did not respond to appropriate first-line treatment, but it is not routinely used for this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Equine-derived antitoxins are immunoglobulins that are derived from the blood of horses that have been immunized with a specific bacterial toxin/toxoid (e.g., botulinum toxin). Equine-derived antitoxins contain foreign proteins that can cause severe allergic reactions in infants and should therefore be avoided in infants with botulism < 1 year of age. The equine-derived heptavalent botulism antitoxin may, however, be used in adults and children > 1 year with wound botulism or food-borne botulism because the risk of hypersensitivity is lower in these patient groups. This type of antitoxin is also considerably cheaper than human-derived antitoxins.
questions.hint: Considering the boy's poor feeding, lack of bowel movements, weak head control, and exposure to honey, he most likely has botulism. Infant botulism is caused by Clostridium botulinum, spores of which may be present in honey. C. botulinum produces a toxin that is absorbed from the gut into the systemic circulation. This toxin blocks the release of acetylcholine from the motor endplate, which causes neuromuscular blockade, resulting in the symptoms seen here.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of progressive weakness and difficulty speaking. She reports difficulty urinating and constipation. Physical examination shows bilateral ptosis, mydriasis, and symmetrical proximal weakness that is more pronounced in the upper extremities. Her speech is slurred and she has difficulty swallowing. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT scan of the head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture would not be diagnostic in this patient as cerebrospinal fluid analysis is typically normal in botulism. This patient's clinical presentation does not suggest CNS infection or inflammatory processes that would require cerebrospinal fluid analysis.

B) INCORRECT:

The edrophonium test is used to diagnose myasthenia gravis by temporarily improving muscle strength through cholinesterase inhibition. However, this patient's presentation with mydriasis, autonomic dysfunction, and descending paralysis pattern is not consistent with myasthenia gravis.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids are not indicated in botulism and would not address the underlying pathophysiology of acetylcholine release inhibition at the neuromuscular junction. Steroids are used in inflammatory conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the head would not be helpful in this patient as the symmetrical, bilateral presentation with cranial nerve palsies and autonomic dysfunction is not consistent with stroke or another structural brain pathology. The pattern of weakness and associated symptoms point to a neuromuscular disorder rather than a CNS pathology.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation (classic triad of cranial nerve palsies, descending paralysis, and autonomic dysfunction) is consistent with botulism. Botulism antitoxin should be administered as soon as possible for all patients with suspected botulism to neutralize unbound neurotoxin, which can prevent the progression of paralysis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of progressive weakness, diplopia, and difficulty swallowing. She had dinner at a family gathering yesterday, where they consumed home-canned vegetables. Physical examination shows bilateral ptosis, mydriasis, dysarthria, and symmetrical proximal muscle weakness that is more pronounced in the upper extremities than lower extremities. She is alert and oriented with normal sensation throughout. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) typically manifests with ascending paralysis that begins in the lower extremities and progresses upward, which is opposite to the descending pattern seen in this patient. Additionally, GBS commonly involves parathesias and hyporeflexia, which are not present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis can cause cranial nerve palsies and muscle weakness, but the pattern is typically fluctuating weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. The acute onset following consumption of home-canned food and the specific pattern of descending paralysis in this patient suggest an alternative diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome typically causes proximal muscle weakness that improves with repetitive or ongoing use. The acute onset and cranial nerve involvement pattern in this patient make an alternative diagnosis more likely.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with clinical features of foodborne botulism with cranial nerve palsies (e.g., ptosis, mydriasis, diplopia, dysarthria), and symmetrical descending muscle weakness affecting proximal muscles more than distal muscles and has had a recent exposure to home-canned vegetables.

E) INCORRECT:

Tick paralysis manifests with ascending paralysis similar to paralysis in Guillain-Barré syndrome, beginning in the lower extremities and progressing upward. The descending pattern and cranial nerve involvement seen in this patient are not characteristic of tick paralysis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with progressive weakness over 18 hours. He reports difficulty swallowing and blurred vision. Physical examination shows bilateral ptosis, mydriasis, and symmetrical proximal muscle weakness. Respiratory assessment shows forced vital capacity of 18 mL/kg, and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are not indicated in botulism management and would not address the respiratory compromise. The paralysis in botulism is due to neurotoxin effects, not inflammatory processes.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The patient meets criteria for mechanical ventilation with forced vital capacity below 20 mL/kg. In botulism, respiratory muscle weakness can progress rapidly, and mechanical ventilation should be initiated when these thresholds are reached to prevent respiratory failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Botulism antitoxin is important in management but does not address the immediate threat to life in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Arterial blood gas analysis may provide additional information but would delay treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Supplemental oxygen alone is inadequate for this patient's respiratory compromise. The oxygen saturation is already acceptable at 96%, indicating that oxygenation is not the primary issue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with confirmed botulism develops a fever in the emergency department. He has descending paralysis, ptosis, and dysphagia. Laboratory results show gram-negative rods in his urine culture. Which antibiotic should be selected to treat his infection while avoiding worsening of his neurological symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that may worsen paralysis in botulism patients. Aminoglycosides pose a risk by potentially enhancing neuromuscular blockade and should be avoided in patients with botulism.

B) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin may pose a risk to patients with botulism by potentially worsening the paralysis. This antibiotic should be avoided when treating concurrent infections in botulism patients.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Ceftriaxone is a safe antibiotic choice for treating infections in botulism patients. Unlike aminoglycosides, clindamycin, and tetracycline, ceftriaxone does not worsen paralysis and can effectively treat gram-negative urinary tract infections without compromising neurological status.

D) INCORRECT:

Tetracycline may pose a risk to patients with botulism and should be avoided as it can potentially worsen the existing paralysis. Alternative antibiotics that do not affect neuromuscular function should be selected.

E) INCORRECT:

Tobramycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that may worsen paralysis in botulism patients.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of double vision, difficulty swallowing, and progressive weakness. She notes the weakness started in her arms and has now moved to her legs. She reports eating home-canned green beans yesterday. On examination, she is alert and oriented, with bilateral ptosis and limited extraocular movements. Motor strength is 3/5 in the upper extremities and 4/5 in the lower extremities. Sensation is intact throughout. Which of the following additional findings is most likely?

choices.text: Hyperreflexia with a positive Babinski sign

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperreflexia and a positive Babinski sign are findings of upper motor neuron lesions, such as those seen in stroke or spinal cord injury. This patient's symmetric, descending weakness is characteristic of a lower motor neuron process, specifically at the neuromuscular junction, which would manifest with hyporeflexia or areflexia, not hyperreflexia.

B) CORRECT:

The botulinum toxin inhibits presynaptic acetylcholine release at both the neuromuscular junction and autonomic synapses. The effect on the parasympathetic nervous system leads to anticholinergic signs. Blockade of cholinergic input to the pupillary sphincter muscle results in unopposed sympathetic tone, causing fixed and dilated pupils (mydriasis). Other autonomic signs include dry mouth, constipation, and urinary retention.

C) INCORRECT:

A fluctuating level of consciousness would suggest a process affecting the brainstem's reticular activating system or bilateral cerebral hemispheres. A key feature of botulism is that patients remain alert and have normal cognition, as the toxin does not cross the blood-brain barrier. This patient is alert and oriented.

D) INCORRECT:

Nuchal rigidity is a sign of meningeal irritation, commonly seen in meningitis or subarachnoid hemorrhage. Although this patient has acute neurologic symptoms, she is alert and oriented, and her presentation of descending paralysis without fever or headache does not suggest a primary meningeal process.

E) INCORRECT:

Loss of vibratory sensation indicates pathology of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord or a large-fiber peripheral neuropathy. However, this patient's sensation is intact. The toxin responsible for her condition affects motor and autonomic transmission but spares sensory pathways.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of acute, symmetric, descending flaccid paralysis with prominent cranial nerve involvement (diplopia, dysphagia, ptosis) after consuming home-canned food is classic for foodborne botulism.
